title: Lesson One
originalHtml:
In Lesson One of the Ranking Evidence Lesson Sequence students begin exploring the question of what makes effective evidence by completing an evidence ranking activity.

For those that have taught or are currently teaching the lesson sequence, notice how your students engage with the lesson.

  • How did your students respond to the lesson?

  • What was most helpful for your students? What was challenging?

For those that are planning to teach the lesson sequence later this year, consider trying out the activities yourself and, based on your experience, reflect on how you imagine your students will engage with the lesson.

  • How do you think your students will respond to the lesson?

  • What do you imagine will be most helpful to them? What might be challenging?

Reflect and Share

Join the Lesson One Discussion and on the Evidence Ranking activity:

  • If you are teaching the lesson sequence now or have already taught it, how did your students respond to the Evidence Ranking? What worked well? What was challenging? Feel free to share pictures of students completing the ranking activity, samples of their rankings, and/or pictures of the Anchor Charts.

  • If you are teaching the lesson sequence later this year, try out the Evidence Ranking activity yourself and share about your experience as a learner. What did you notice about your rankings? What did it make you think about the Anchor Chart question: What Makes Good Evidence? Based on your experience, how do you imagine your students will respond to the Evidence Ranking?
